details.title: Multiple Weighted Objectives Heuristic for the Redundancy Allocation Problem

p: David W. Coit is an Associate Professor in the Department of Industrial & Systems Engineering at Rutgers University. He received a BS degree in Mechanical Engineering from Cornell University, an MBA from Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, and MS & PhD in Industrial Engineering from the University of Pittsburgh. In 1999, he was awarded a CAREER grant from NSF to study reliability optimization. He also has over ten years of experience working for IIT Research Institute (IITRI), Rome, NY, where he was a reliability analyst, project manager, and an engineering group manager. His current research involves reliability prediction & optimization, risk analysis, and multi-criteria optimization considering uncertainty.

Abdullah Konak is an Assistant Professor of Information Sciences and Technology at Penn State Berks. He received his B.S. degree in Industrial Engineering from Yildiz Technical University, his M.S. in Industrial Engineering from Bradley University, and his Ph.D. in Industrial Engineering from University of Pittsburgh. Previous to this position, he was an instructor in the Department of Systems and Industrial Engineering at Auburn University for two years. His current research interest is in the application of Operations Research techniques to complex problems, including such topics as telecommunication network design, network reliability analysis/optimization, facilities design, and data mining.

details.abstract: A new heuristic is proposed and tested for system reliability optimization. The multiple weighted objective heuristic is based on a transformation of the problem into a multiple objective optimization problem, and then ultimately, transformation into a different single objective problem. The multiple objectives are to simultaneously maximize the reliability of each individual subsystem. This is a logical approach because system reliability is the product of the subsystem reliabilities, so if they are maximized, the system reliability will also be high. This new formulation and associated heuristic are then based on solving a sequence of linear programming problems. It is one of the very few optimization approaches that allow for linear programming algorithms and software to be used for the redundancy allocation problem when mixing of functionally equivalent components is allowed. Thus, it represents an efficient solution method that relies on readily available optimization tools. The heuristic is tested on many example problems, and compared to competing solution approaches. Overall, the heuristic performance is observed to be very good on the tested problem, and superior to the max-min heuristic regarding both efficiency, and performance

references.title: Optimal Reliability Design: Fundamentals and Applications

context.text: Kuo [1] provide a comprehensive review on system reliability optimization.
Kuo [1] also provides a summary of these heuristic approaches.

references.text: W. Kuo, V. Prasad, F. Tillman, C. L. Hwang, Optimal Reliability Design: Fundamentals and Applications, 2000, Cambridge University Press.

references.title:
On the computational complexity of reliability redundancy
allocation in a series system

context.text: For series-parallel systems with a single objective, Chern [2] demonstrated that the redundancy allocation problem is NP-hard.

references.text: M. S. Chern, "On the computational complexity of reliability redundancy allocation in a series system", Operations Research Letters, vol. 11, pp. 309-315, June 1992.

references.title:
System reliability allocation problem and
a computational algorithm

context.text: Fyffe [3] used dynamic programming to solve the redundancy allocation problem by limiting the problem to only one type of component available for each subsystem.
The first test problem originally proposed by Fyffe [3] includes 14 subsystems with three or four component choices for each subsystem.

links.abstract: The detailed allocation method of system reliability discussed in this paper is designed to select the optimal solution in the context of the trade-off analysis. It is noted that the problem may be structured as an n-stage sequential decision problem. A computational algorithm is developed using dynamic programming.

references.text: D. E. Fyffe, W. W. Hines, N. K. Lee, "System reliability allocation problem and a computational algorithm", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, vol. 17, pp. 64-69, June 1968.

references.title:
Surrogate constraints algorithm for reliability
optimization problems with two constraints

context.text: Nakagawa & Miyazaki [4] demonstrated that a surrogate constraints approach is efficient to accommodate multiple constraints with dynamic programming.
This problem was also used by many other researchers [4], [6], [7], [13].

links.abstract: This paper presents an algorithm (called the N&M algorithm) for solving pure-integer separable nonlinear programming problems with two constraints. The N&M algorithm uses surrogate constraints and solves a given problem by effectively generating values of surrogate multiplier (i.e., surrogate problems) and solving the surrogate problems. Examples show that the N&M algorithm is superior to dynamic programming using the Lagrange multiplier in terms of number of iterations and narrowness of gap.

references.text: Y. Nakagawa, S. Miyazaki, "Surrogate constraints algorithm for reliability optimization problems with two constraints", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, vol. 30, pp. 175-180, 1981.

references.title: Optimal redundancy for reliability in series system

context.text: Integer programming [5], genetic algorithms (GA) [6], and tabu search [7] have also been applied to determine the optimal design configuration.

references.text: P. M. Ghare, R. E. Taylor, "Optimal redundancy for reliability in series system", Operations Research, vol. 17, pp. 838-847, September 1969.

references.title:
Reliability optimization for series-parallel
systems using a genetic algorithm

context.text: Integer programming [5], genetic algorithms (GA) [6], and tabu search [7] have also been applied to determine the optimal design configuration.
Coit & Smith [6] demonstrated that consideration of component mixing increased the problem solution space, thereby resulting in higher maximum system reliability values.
This problem was also used by many other researchers [4], [6], [7], [13].

As in Coit & Smith [6], and Kulturel-Konak [7], 33 variations of the unrestricted problem, where mixing functionally equal components within subsystems is allowed, were studied by fixing the cost constraint limit \$C\$ at 130, and changing the weight constraint limit \$W\$ from 159 to 191.
The best results for these 33 problems were generally found by the GA approach of Coit & Smith [6], or the TS approach of Kulturel-Konak [7].

links.abstract: A problem-specific genetic algorithm (GA) is developed and demonstrated to analyze series-parallel systems and to determine the optimal design configuration when there are multiple component choices available for each of several k-out-of-n:G subsystems. The problem is to select components and redundancy-levels to optimize some objective function, given system-level constraints on reliability, cost, and/or weight. Previous formulations of the problem have implicit restrictions concerning the type...

references.text: D. W. Coit, A. E. Smith, "Reliability optimization for series-parallel systems using a genetic algorithm", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, vol. 45, no. 2, pp. 254-260, June 1996.

references.title:
Efficiently solving the redundancy allocation problem using
Tabu search

context.text: Integer programming [5], genetic algorithms (GA) [6], and tabu search [7] have also been applied to determine the optimal design configuration.
This problem was also used by many other researchers [4], [6], [7], [13].

As in Coit & Smith [6], and Kulturel-Konak [7], 33 variations of the unrestricted problem, where mixing functionally equal components within subsystems is allowed, were studied by fixing the cost constraint limit \$C\$ at 130, and changing the weight constraint limit \$W\$ from 159 to 191.
The best results for these 33 problems were generally found by the GA approach of Coit & Smith [6], or the TS approach of Kulturel-Konak [7].

These three problems were solved for 36 different combinations of cost & weight constraint limits by using the MWO2 heuristic, and the TS approach of Kulturel-Konak [7], which found most of the best reported solutions for Problem 1.

references.text: S. Kulturel-Konak, A. E. Smith, D. W. Coit, "Efficiently solving the redundancy allocation problem using Tabu search", IIE Transactions, vol. 35, no. 6, pp. 515-526, June 2003.

references.title:
Branch and bound redundancy optimization
for a series system with multiple-choice constraints

context.text: Other approaches [8] include the solution space reduction procedure, and branch-and-bound to find the optimal solution with multiple component choices.

links.abstract: This paper considers a redundancy optimization problem in which multiple-choice and resource constraints are incorporated. The problem is expressed as a nonlinear integer programming problem and is characterized as an NP-hard problem. The purpose of the paper is to develop a SSRP (solution space reduction procedure). Therefore, the problem is analyzed first to characterize some solution properties. An iterative SSRP is then derived using those solution properties. Finally, the iterative SSRP is ...

references.text: C. S. Sung, Y. K. Cho, "Branch and bound redundancy optimization for a series system with multiple-choice constraints", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, vol. 48, no. 2, pp. 108-117, June 1999.

references.title:
A heuristic method for determining optimal
reliability allocation

context.text: Nakagawa & Nakashima [9] developed a very useful heuristic for problems with multiple component choices.
Determine a feasible solution \$({\bf x}^{\circ})\$ to the problem using any available method, e.g., a greedy heuristic such as Nakagawa-Nakashima [9], or Li [11].
The max-min heuristic has been demonstrated [14] to generally yield superior solutions based on numerous randomly generated problems, and comparisons to the Nakagawa & Nakashima heuristic [9].

links.abstract: The paper presents a method for obtaining an optimal reliability allocation of an n-stage series system. In each stage, redundant comnponents can be added (in parallel, stand-by, or k-out-of-n:G, etc.), or a more reliable component can be used in order to improve the system reliability. The solution is obtained by repeatedly using a more reliable candidate at each stage that has the greatest value of a `weighted sensitivity function'. The balance between the objective unction and the constraints...

references.text: Y. Nakagawa, K. Nakashima, "A heuristic method for determining optimal reliability allocation", IEEE Transaction on Reliability, vol. 26, pp. 156-161, 1977.

references.title: A note on heuristic method for in optimal system reliability

context.text: Kuo [10] later extended this research by modifying the sensitivity factor with impressive results.

links.abstract: Many optimization techniques have been used to solve redundancy allocation problems, most of which result in noninteger solutions. A few, including dynamic programming and integer programming, as well as a host of heuristic methods give integer solutions. This note critically reviews six promising heuristic approaches. The advantages and disadvantages of each of the approaches are discussed. An extended approach is presented which incorporates some of the ideas of the previous methods for solvin...

references.text: W. Kou, C. L. Hwang, F. A. Tillman, "A note on heuristic method for in optimal system reliability", IEEE Transaction on Reliability, vol. 27, pp. 320-324, 1978.

references.title:
A bound heuristic algorithm for solving reliability redundancy
optimization

context.text: Li [11] also presents an interesting heuristic based on a bounded region.
Determine a feasible solution \$({\bf x}^{\circ})\$ to the problem using any available method, e.g., a greedy heuristic such as Nakagawa-Nakashima [9], or Li [11].

references.text: J. Li, "A bound heuristic algorithm for solving reliability redundancy optimization", Microelectronics & Reliability, vol. 36, no. 3, pp. 335-339, 1996.

references.title:
A linear approximation for redundant reliability problems
with multiple component choices

context.text: Hsieh [12] presented a linear approximation of system reliability which resulted in efficient solutions to the problem.

references.text: Y. C. Hsieh, "A linear approximation for redundant reliability problems with multiple component choices", Computers & Industrial Engineering, vol. 44, pp. 91-103, 2002.

references.title:
Reliability optimization of series-parallel systems using
a max-min approach

context.text: Ramirez [13] presented the max-min heuristic for this problem.
This problem was also used by many other researchers [4], [6], [7], [13].
The MWO heuristic is based on a concept similar to the max-min heuristic of Ramirez-Marquez [13].

references.text: J. E. Ramirez-Marquez, D. W. Coit, A. Konak, "Reliability optimization of series-parallel systems using a max-min approach", IIE Transactions, vol. 36, no. 9, September 2004.

references.title:
Comparison of max-min approach
and NN method for reliability optimization of series-parallel system

context.text: Lee [14] performed numerous problem simulations, and compared the max-min heuristic with the Nakagawa & Nakashima heuristic.
The max-min heuristic has been demonstrated [14] to generally yield superior solutions based on numerous randomly generated problems, and comparisons to the Nakagawa & Nakashima heuristic [9].

references.text: H. Lee, W. Kuo, C. Ha, "Comparison of max-min approach and NN method for reliability optimization of series-parallel system", Journal of System Science and Systems Engineering, vol. 12, no. 1, pp. 39-48, 2003.

references.title:
Structure optimization of power system with different redundant
elements

context.text: Levitin [15] also presented one of the first papers devoted to component mixing for the reliability allocation problem.

references.text: G. Levitin, A. Lisnianski, D. Elmakis, "Structure optimization of power system with different redundant elements", Electric Power Systems Research, vol. 43, pp. 19-27, 1997.

references.title:
Variance of system reliability estimates with arbitrarily
repeated components

context.text: There are other benefits to mixing functionally equivalent components including a potentially reduced system reliability estimation variance [16], and reduced susceptibility to common cause failures.

links.abstract: A model is developed to determine the variance of system reliability estimates and to estimate confidence intervals for series-parallel systems with arbitrarily repeated components. For these systems, different copies of the same component-type are used several or many times within the system, but only a single reliability estimate is available for each distinct component-type. The single estimate is used everywhere the component appears in the system design, and component estimation-error is th...

references.text: T. Jin, D. W. Coit, "Variance of system reliability estimates with arbitrarily repeated components", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, vol. 50, no. 4, pp. 409-413, December 2001.

references.title:
Optimal apportionment of reliability &
redundancy in series systems under multiple objectives

context.text: Dhingra [17] applied a multiple-criteria optimization approach to maximize system reliability, and minimize resource consumption (cost, weight, and volume).

links.abstract: A multiobjective reliability apportionment problem for a series system with time-dependent reliability is presented. The resulting mathematical programming formulation determines the optimal level of component reliability and the number of redundant components at each stage. The problem is a multiobjective, nonlinear, mixed-integer mathematical programming problem, subject to several design constraints. Sequential unconstrained minimization techniques in conjunction with heuristic algorithms are...

references.text: A. Dhingra, "Optimal apportionment of reliability & redundancy in series systems under multiple objectives", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, vol. 41, no. 4, pp. 576-582, 1992.

references.title:
An
effective approach for multiple criteria redundancy optimization problems

context.text: Misra & Sharma [18], [19] used integer programming, and a min-max concept to obtain Pareto optimal solutions.

references.text: K. Misra, U. Sharma, "An effective approach for multiple criteria redundancy optimization problems", Microelectronics and Reliability, vol. 31, no. 2/3, pp. 303-321, 1991.

references.title:
Multi-criteria optimization
for combined reliability and redundancy allocation in systems employing mixed
redundancies

context.text: Misra & Sharma [18], [19] used integer programming, and a min-max concept to obtain Pareto optimal solutions.

references.text: K. Misra, U. Sharma, "Multi-criteria optimization for combined reliability and redundancy allocation in systems employing mixed redundancies", Microelectronics and Reliability, vol. 31, no. 2/3, pp. 323-335, 1991.

references.title:
Interactive parametric dynamic programming and its application
of large system reliability

context.text: Li [20] considered dynamic programming to solve Dhingra's problem.

references.text: D. Li, "Interactive parametric dynamic programming and its application of large system reliability", Journal of Mathematical Analysis and Applications, vol. 191, pp. 589-607, 1995.

references.title:
System optimization considering component reliability estimation
uncertainty: a multi-criteria approach

context.text: Coit [21] proposed a multiple objective formulation where the objectives were to maximize an estimate of the system reliability, and to minimize the variance of that estimate.

links.abstract: Summary & Conclusions-This paper addresses system reliability optimization when component reliability estimates are treated as random variables with estimation uncertainty. System reliability optimization algorithms generally assume that component reliability values are known exactly, i.e., they are deterministic. In practice, that is rarely the case. For risk-averse system design, the estimation uncertainty, propagated from the component estimates, may result in unacceptable estimation uncertai...

references.text: D. W. Coit, T. Jin, N. Wattanapongsakorn, "System optimization considering component reliability estimation uncertainty: a multi-criteria approach", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, vol. 53, no. 3, September 2004.

references.title:
Multiobjective optimization by genetic algorithms: application
to safety systems

context.text: Busacca [22] proposed a Multiple Objective Genetic Algorithm (MOGA).

references.text: P. G. Busacca, M. Marseguerra, E. Zio, "Multiobjective optimization by genetic algorithms: application to safety systems", Reliability Engineering & System Safety, vol. 72, pp. 59-74, 2001.

references.title: Decisions With Multiple Objectives: Preferences and Value Tradeoffs

context.text: More complex utility functions are available [23], but the most straightforward approach is to combine the multiple objectives using the weighted sum of multiple objective functions. \$\omega_{i}\$ is defined as the weight assigned to the \$i^{\rm th}\$ objective, i.e., subsystem reliability.

references.text: R. L. Keeney, H. Raiffa, Decisions With Multiple Objectives: Preferences and Value Tradeoffs, 1993, Cambridge University Press.
